rsbNotes.title: Ezra 3–6
rsbNotes.text: 3:1–6:22 The people rebuild the altar, resume the sacrifices (3:1–6), and then rebuild the temple itself (3:7–6:22). Spurred on by the prophets Haggai and Zechariah (5:1–2) and blessed by God (5:5), they succeed in spite of opposition from the peoples around them (ch. 4) and the governor of “the province Beyond the River,” (5:3–6:12).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 3:1
rsbNotes.text: 3:1 the seventh month. This was Tishri (September-October), the month of the Feast of Booths (Lev. 23:33–44). The desire to celebrate this feast (3:4) no doubt provided the stimulus needed to rebuild the altar.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 3:2
rsbNotes.text:
3:2 burnt offerings. Burnt offerings were the primary offerings (Lev. 1), but others are also in view (v. 5). The burnt offering was the continuing basis on which a sinful people could live in the presence of a holy God (Ex. 29:42), looking forward as it did to the sacrifice of Christ, as the final sacrifice that brings sinners into the presence of God (Heb. 10:19–20).

as it is written. The written word was a powerful tool used by God to accomplish His redemptive plan.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 3:3
rsbNotes.text: 3:3 fear was on them. They had the courage to build the altar and lay the foundation of the temple. But their courage would soon be tested (4:4–5), and the work would be stopped (4:24).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 3:4–6
rsbNotes.text: 3:4–6 Not only was the Feast of Booths celebrated, but the entire sacrificial system was set in motion, because the sacrifices were a part of maintaining the covenant relationship (Heb. 9:22). So important were the sacrifices that they were started before the temple itself was finished.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 3:7
rsbNotes.text: 3:7 Provisions were made immediately to begin rebuilding the temple. The language of v. 7 recalls the materials assembled for Solomon’s temple (1 Chr. 22:2–4; 2 Chr. 2:8–16).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 3:8
rsbNotes.text:
3:8 the second year. 536 b.c.

the second month. This is Ziv (or Iyar, April-May), the same time of year that Solomon began building the original temple (2 Chr. 3:2).

to supervise the work of the house of the Lord. This phrasing is virtually identical to the language used about Solomon’s temple (1 Chr. 23:4).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 3:10
rsbNotes.text: 3:10 when the builders laid the foundation. The focus of the narrative is the response of the people rather than the mechanics of construction. If the return of the temple articles encouraged the spirits of the people (1:9–11 note), much more did the laying of the foundation confirm their faith in God, who had promised restoration after exile (Deut. 30:1–5). Their expression of praise echoes exactly the dedication of Solomon’s temple (2 Chr. 5:13).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 3:12
rsbNotes.text: 3:12 But many . . . wept. The tears of the older members of the community were not tears of joy, but tears of disappointment because of the contrast between this small beginning (cf. Zech. 4:10) and the splendor of Solomon’s temple. Similar disappointment would later call for rebuke (Hag. 2:1–5), but for the moment the joy of the Lord was the strength of many.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:1
rsbNotes.text: 4:1 the adversaries. Though these people came with apparently good intentions, they are referred to as “adversaries,” since they later tried to undermine the work of restoration. There was some political motivation in this conflict, because only returnees had authorization from Cyrus to undertake construction (1:2–4). But ultimately the trouble was religious. The “adversaries” were people from various places who had been transplanted into Samaria, the area north of Judah, after the destruction of the northern kingdom of Israel in 722 b.c. (4:9–10 note). They worshiped many gods and incorporated worship of the Lord into their polytheism (2 Kin. 17:24–41). The animosity between the Jews and the Samaritans who descended from these “adversaries” forms part of the background of the New Testament (cf. John 4:1–42).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:3
rsbNotes.text: 4:3 we alone will build. The discrimination was not racial or political, but religious. From the early days of living in the Promised Land (Judg. 3:6) and throughout their history (2 Kin. 17:7–17), alliances with foreigners led the Israelites into idolatry and ultimately to exile from the land (2 Kin. 17:18–23). The failure of the returnees to separate themselves from the indigenous population became a problem before long (Ezra 9; 10). The same principle of religious separation is still operative under the new covenant (2 Cor. 6:14–7:1).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:4
rsbNotes.text: 4:4 the people of the land. The “adversaries” of v. 1.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:5
rsbNotes.text: 4:5 bribed counselors. Perhaps these were Persian officials. The obstructive efforts of the adversaries caused a delay in the work from the time of Cyrus (550–530 b.c.) until the second year of Darius (522–486 b.c.).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:6–23
rsbNotes.text: 4:6–23 This material is a separate section, describing opposition to rebuilding the wall after Darius and during the reigns of Xerxes (486–465 b.c.) and Artaxerxes I (465–424 b.c.). The narrative justifies calling the neighboring peoples in v. 1 “adversaries.” Second, it shows that opposition was not a brief and passing problem, but a foretaste of prolonged opposition to the people of God in rebuilding God’s ‘‘house”—the temple, but also the city and the nation.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:6
rsbNotes.text:
4:6 Ahasuerus. Ahasuerus (Xerxes) succeeded Darius and was king of Persia from 486 to 465 b.c.

they wrote an accusation. The subject of the verb is not specified, but the context shows that the troublemakers were a later generation of the “adversaries” of v. 1. Nothing is said about the nature of the accusation.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:7
rsbNotes.text:
4:7 Artaxerxes. Artaxerxes I, successor to Ahasuerus (Xerxes) and king of Persia from 465 to 424 b.c.

wrote to Artaxerxes. There is no information about the content of this letter, but considering the context it was doubtless an effort to prevent rebuilding the wall.

Aramaic. This was the language of international diplomacy in the ancient Near East.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:8–6:18
rsbNotes.text: 4:8–6:18 This section is written not in Hebrew, but Aramaic, the language of the original documents. The correspondence expresses the concern of various Gentile officials about the progress of the Jews’ work.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:8
rsbNotes.text: 4:8 scribe. Scribes were high officials who wrote official correspondence and kept archival records for the provincial government (7:6 note).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:9
rsbNotes.text: 4:9 the rest of their associates. The opposition did not come from a few, but was broadly based.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:10
rsbNotes.text:
4:10 Osnappar. Probably Ashurbanipal, the last successful king of Assyria (668–627 b.c.), who transplanted various peoples into Samaria. This practice was begun after the fall of Samaria in 722 b.c., probably by Sargon II (2 Kin. 17:24).

Beyond the River. The area west of the Euphrates, including Aram, Phoenicia, and Palestine.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:12
rsbNotes.text: 4:12 finishing the walls. See note 4:6–23.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:14
rsbNotes.text: 4:14 we eat the salt of the palace. Lit. “we have salted with the salt of the palace.” Probably this is a way of referring to the covenantal obligation of a vassal to his overlord (cf. Lev. 2:13; Num. 18:19; 2 Chr. 13:5).

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:15
rsbNotes.text:
4:15 book of the records. The various Aramaic documents used in writing this section of Ezra would have been kept in a similar archive.

a rebellious city . . . was laid waste. See 2 Kin. 18:7; 24:1.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:16
rsbNotes.text: 4:16 have no possession. Obviously an exaggeration, these words were intended to sway Artaxerxes.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:18
rsbNotes.text: 4:18 has been plainly read. The king was not given a summary of the letter; it was read to him word for word.

rsbNotes.title: Ezra 4:20
rsbNotes.text: 4:20 Israel once received tribute from other nations, under David and Solomon. Now, even though they have returned to the Land of Promise, God’s people must submit to the rule of the ungodly (9:9 and note).
